biogHist.abstract: The Seaforth Salvation Army Boys' Reformatory was run by the Salvation Army on a large site in Gosnells from 1920 until it closed in 1955. The reformatory was co-located with the Seaforth Boys' Home (1920-1955), the Seaforth Salvation Army Girls' Home (1920-1942) and the Seaforth Todders' Home (1945-1949). Since 1955, the Seaforth site has been used by the Salvation Army for adult residential facilities.
biogHist.p: The Seaforth Salvation Army Boys' Reformatory was run by the Salvation Army on a large site in Gosnells from 1920 until it closed in 1955.

The Reformatory section was set towards the rear of the Seaforth site, on the northern side of the Canning River, and accommodated boys aged 14 to 18 years. The reformatory was described in the Salvation Army newspaper, War Cry on 26 November 1921: the existing homestead on the estate housed three dormitories (with room for ten, three and nine boys each), a vegetable garden in the 'swamp land' north of a five acre citrus orchard; and a schoolhouse that was in process of being erected, with boys having lessons in the dining-hall behind the administration block.

In 1925, an article in the War Cry, reported that there were two dormitories, 'a little reading-room where the lads spend their evenings', a patch of land for football and a cricket pitch. The boys from the reformatory were 'the farmers' of Seaforth, being trained and working on agricultural pursuits. When the boys had learned some farming skills and 'the greater art of mastering themselves', they were placed on farms and stations. The wages these boys earned were banked by the Seaforth Manager and held in trust. The article reported that there was &pound3,000 in the account in December 1925.

In 1943, the Royal Commission appointed to Inquire into the Care and Reform of Youthful Delinquents inspected Seaforth and observed that there was a need for a trades school because 'all boys are not adapted' to just learning about farming. A Trades School was built at Seaforth in 1945, with boys making around 15,000 bricks in four months. The Trades School was dedicated by Commissioner WR Dalziel, Territorial Commander, on 1 September 1945.

In 1953, the Premier of Western Australia commissioned RH Hicks, Director of Child Welfare and Social Services in New South Wales, to review Western Australian child welfare facilities, including the Seaforth Salvation Army Boys' Reformatory. Hicks' report was never released by the government but certain elements were published in the press, including information that condemned the conditions at Seaforth.
The Seaforth Salvation Army Boys' Reformatory closed on 10 August 1955.

chronItem.event: Location - The Salvation Army ran a 'reformatory' for boys on the Seaforth property along Albany Highway, Gosnells

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Seaforth School and Reformatory Boys

archref.abstract: 'Seaforth School and Reformatory Boys' 1947' is a digital copy of four photocopied images mounted on a single piece of paper and held in the Seaforth photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. Handwritten captions identify the images as 'Seaforth School'; 'Seaforth - Reformatory boys'; 'Seaforth 7-7-54' (boys are named in the original held on the file); and 'Seaforth 1954 F. Dean & Blinkie'. From the clothing, it seems likely that all images of the boys date from 1954.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Seaforth Boys Home 1947

archref.abstract: 'Seaforth Boys Home 1947' is a digital copy of two images mounted on a single piece of paper and held in the Seaforth photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. A typed caption reads: 'Seaforth Boys Home - 1947 On left is Lieut. Ron Dunshea oversighting boys making bricks'. The other image is a clipping from the War Cry showing the stable that had been converted to a chapel at Seaforth.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Seaforth MacKenzie Home at Seaforth Boy's Home, 1951

archref.unittitle: Seaforth MacKenzie Home at Seaforth Boy's Home, 1951
archref.abstract: 'Seaforth MacKenzie Home at Seaforth Boy's Home, 1951' is a digital copy of four images mounted on paper and held in the Seaforth photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. A typed caption identifies the images as a photograph of the homestead used for the Seaforth Boys' Home; a photograph of boys in the Canning River, tending cattle in 1951; buildings, including the workshop; and Brigadier Sam McCormack with boys in the workshop. As boys from the reformatory used the workshop, it is possible that the images are relevant to both the Seaforth Boys' Home and the Seaforth Salvation Army Boys' Reformatory.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Seaforth Reformatory 1931

archref.unitid: Seaforth Boys closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Seaforth Reformatory 1931' a digital copy of an image held in the Seaforth Boys closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. A typed caption dates the image to 1931.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Seaforth WA Children's Homes 1920's

archref.unitid: Seaforth Boys closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Seaforth WA Children's Homes 1920's' is a digital copy of an item held in the Seaforth Boys closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It is a collection of photocopied images relating to the children's Homes run by the Salvation Army on the Seaforth site at Gosnells: Seaforth Boys' Home; Seaforth Salvation Army Girls' Home; and Seaforth Salvation Army Boys' Reformatory. There are images of children, staff, buildings and grounds. Some images have typewritten captions.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Seaforth History

archref.unitid: Seaforth Boys closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Seaforth history' is a digital copy of an undated item held in the Seaforth Boys closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It is a typed list of major historical events (such as openings and closings) and key staff movements at the Seaforth Boys' Home and Reformatory. It is likely that the list was compiled from the official 'History Book' for the institution. The years 1939-1974 are covered, extending beyond the period when Seaforth was a children's Home.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Backward boys come to the front

archref.unittitle: Backward boys come to the front
archref.unitid: Seaforth Boys closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Backward boys come to the front' is a digital copy of an item published in the War Cry Christmas edition on 19 December 1925, held in the Seaforth Boys closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. Written by Captain Jean Brown, the item reports that the Seaforth Boys' Home has 50 boys in the 'backward' section. There are images of boys and staff, and a view of the Home, which is described as a 'village-like estate'. The item also describes the boys' 'general' section and the Seaforth Salvation Army Boys' Reformatory.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: BA953/52: Display of cane furniture made by the boys at Seaforth Boys' Home, Gosnells, 1930

archref.unittitle: BA953/52: Display of cane furniture made by the boys at Seaforth Boys' Home, Gosnells, 1930
archref.unitid: State Library of Western Australia Call Number BA953/7, 24-36, 39-43, 45-53, 55-60
archref.abstract: This is a digitised copy of a photographic print and is part of the group of images 'Canework, woodwork and other goods made by the boys at Seaforth Boys' Home, Gosnells [picture]' held at the State Library of Western Australia. The image shows a selection of cane furniture made by the boys at the Home.
archref.note: For personal use only. To publish or display, contact the State Library of Western Australia.
